metadata.notes: Delivered at the National Cathedral, 2006. Short duration (8 minutes).

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a strong Critical Parent voice to interrogate the listener's failures, using rhetorical 'why' questions to induce guilt and highlight inadequacy.
quotes: Why are you so neglectful of your obligations?
Why are you giving away so little of your substance?
Why is the service of God only one thing among many things in your life?

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent appears at the end as a 'Rescuer' figure, but it is conditional on the listener first accepting their 'wretched' status.
quotes: The deepest meaning of the Christian story is that we have been delivered by the self-offering of the Good Shepherd

adult.analysis: The sermon bypasses the Adult ego state. It does not invite logical reflection or practical agency; instead, it explicitly denies the listener's Adult capacity ('we have no power of ourselves').
quotes: we have no power of ourselves to help ourselves

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The preacher speaks as a 'dying man to dying men,' a posture of the Adapted Child (melancholy/fear) and invites the congregation into a 'Wretched' Adapted Child state.
quotes: The boy, looking alarmed, says, 'I don’t know.'
Wretched human being that I am!

free_child_FC.analysis: There is almost no Free Child spontaneity. The tone is somber, heavy, and focused on captivity rather than the creative joy of faith.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher establishes a Parent-Child dynamic where the preacher (as CP) scolds the listener (as AC), then shifts to a shared AC position ('the whole lot of us') before pointing to a Divine Parent.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social transaction is an exploration of a biblical text (A->A), but the psychological transaction is a shaming maneuver (CP->AC) to create a sense of helplessness.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the rhetorical questions. They aren't seeking information; they are designed to trigger a 'not-OK' feeling in the listener.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch (Redemption)

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of wisdom through the Cherokee wolf story.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire to be 'good' and 'disciplined'.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher suddenly declares the listener is incapable of feeding the good wolf ('Left to ourselves, we will feed the carnivorous wolf every time').
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels 'wretched' and dependent on the preacher's solution.

evidence_quotes: You want to do the right thing, don’t you?
Then why are you so neglectful...?

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Discussing the state of the world and the movie 'Crash'.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from specific problems to a universal 'bondage to decay'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A collective sense of helplessness and shared misery.

evidence_quotes: The ugly America is arrogant, bullying, triumphalist.
world without end... bondage to decay.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High: Positions the 'Good Shepherd' (and by extension the sermon's message) as the only way out of the 'body of death'.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium: Uses the Critical Parent voice to point out the listener's stinginess and sloth.
preacher_roles.victim: Medium: Identifies as a 'dying man' and 'wretched,' pulling the audience into a shared victimhood under 'the law of sin'.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: The congregation is pushed into the Victim role—powerless to 'feed the wolf' or help themselves.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The sermon reinforces dependency on an external Rescuer rather than developing the listener's Adult ego to make conscious, autonomous choices.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: While theologically orthodox in a traditional Pauline sense, the sermon is psychologically regressive. it systematically deconstructs the listener's 'Adult' agency ('we have no power') to induce a 'Not-OK' Child state. By using the 'Bait & Switch' game, the preacher creates a psychological vacuum of guilt and helplessness that only his specific religious 'food' can fill. This creates a cycle of dependency rather than spiritual maturity or autonomy.
strengths: Strong use of metaphor (the wolves) to engage the Child ego.
areas_for_improvement: Total negation of the Adult ego's capacity for choice.
Use of shame as a primary motivational tool.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try addressing the congregation as 'Adults' who are capable of making observations about their own lives. Instead of 'Why are you so neglectful?' (CP), ask 'What factors in our current environment make it difficult to remain disciplined?' (Adult). This invites cooperation rather than submission.
